results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on learning analytics (LA) and its relation to learning design (LD). It mentions the use of techniques like CDM, ENA, and SNA.
Sections 3.1 (Study Setting), 3.2 (Data Preparation), and 3.3 (Data Analysis) provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, from data collection to analysis techniques.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.

The document states: "The study was conducted at a the University of Zagreb...we focused on one lecturing group, including 169 students." and "The study was conducted with a positive opinion of the Ethics Committee of the higher education institution." implying privacy concerns prevent open data sharing.

The document describes the data collection process and provides details about the variables (e.g., LO weights, assessment points, student grades) and their formats (e.g., percentage grades, binary mapping).
Data collection methods are fully described, including extraction of student grades from the Moodle LMS, weekly quizzes, exams, and a problem-solving essay.
The document does not state that the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
There is no justification provided for why the code is not shared.
The document mentions using R and specific packages (CDM, rENA) for data analysis, but does not state whether the data preparation code is shared.
Statistical tests and models (CDM, ENA, SNA) are clearly described, including their purpose and application.
Average mastery scores, percentages, and centrality metrics are reported, providing quantitative results.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
Data coding and analysis are not described in a qualitative manner, as the focus is on statistical analysis.
Results are presented in tables (Table 1, Table 2, Table 3, Table 4) and figures (Figure 1, Figure 2, Figure 3, Figure 5, Figure 6), with clear descriptions and interpretations.
Section 5.3 explicitly discusses limitations of the study, including sample size, context specificity, and methodological considerations.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
